reviews.review_text: Item was delivered when expected and without damage.

I do??? !!!! Understand.Hmm.I am glad I read this novel at this point in my life. I guess, I was born and raised to be a Peter Keating until I found a Roark Howard in my mind, stubborn and unflinching, while writing Yin-Yang series. I will not go back to being Peter Keating. No matter what.That said, the first night scene between Roark and Dominique was distasteful. How could a writer of Rand's caliber go wrong with basics?Two, the answer is not black OR white. The answer lies in seeing the black in white and the white in black.It's not dependence vs. independence, it's to know WHERE to be dependent and WHEN to be independent.

Along with Atlas Shrugged, two of the most straight forward, honest, objective stories embracing in a prophetic manner, the reality we are facing in our own generation.  Anyone not seeing Ayn’s insight and clearly accurate story parallels to our own generation and the very authentic, real possibilities presented misses the point of Ms. Rands mastery.  It’s time people realized the truth and Ayn says it very clearly. Amazing read... long, wordy at times, but appropriately so and worth the time to read. Engaging, can’t put down reading.
very thought provoking. Open your eyes people this is going on right now.

And wanted to read it again.  She is a great author.  Her work gives your mind alot of thought. Its not a easy read.  It is very different than the authors today which is what makes this a great read.  You have to think and you see how it relates to the 2000 years. The book was wrote in the 30,s. You want to read something wit alot of substance  read the fountainhead.  I want to see the movie starring Gary cooper and patrica Neil.

Though I did not love all 750 pages, I absolutely recommend this book and felt it expanded me in meanginful ways and was brilliantly conceived and written. At times the masochistic nature of the characters and storyline felt so intense that it scared me on an existential level. However, there is love and brilliant insight at the core of it; true,unbridled love in the nakedness of self-acceptance, fearlessness, personal responsibility,  and happiness.  It's an astonishing book. (And the romance is intense!) Forget about Rand's later political movement and how extremists have used that negatively, and just enjoy the sheer intelligence and creativity of this read!

Roark's success is based on his adherence to rational principles.  Wynand's downfall is based on his adherence to pragmatism in an irrational world.  Toohey's success is predicated on the un-reason that dominates the collectivist world; like the Emperor's New Clothes, one accepts the imbecilic under threat that rejection of it will lead to rejection of oneself.  Rand is often criticized as a writer for her protagonists' impossibly lengthy and philosophical speeches.  Although I am somewhat sympathetic to that, I have encountered some people who really do things like that; mostly religionists who can't help themselves from puking up all their faith-based propaganda in the hopes that the flurry of ideas will somehow cow another person into acceptance.  Also, whenever I have tried to have a philosophical dialogue with people, they soon glaze over and recognize that their only way out is to offer irrational objections until you pin them down to - they simply use emotions as bases for their beliefs.  So I cut my conversations short.

Howard Roark is an architect who does not comply with the norm. For this, society criticizes him and tries to destroy his career. Impervious to all, he marches to the beat of his own drum and rises to the top. He becomes the fountainhead of achievement.The Fountainhead is a fascinating look at how a collective mindset can ruin the individual. It is the individual who achieves and creates. Attempting to stifle the individual results in failure to advance as a society. Society will remain in the quagmire of mediocrity.Ayn Rand does a brilliant job in creating a cast of characters that contrasts with Mr. Roark and illustrates the problems of society. Peter Keating, Roark's architect rival, represents mediocrity. Elsworth Toohey, who instantly sees Mr. Roark as a threat, represents socialism. As is typical with Ayn Rand, many of the character's speeches are lengthy commentaries that reflect her philosophy. In reality, most characters would not speak that way. It is however, interesting to have a glimpse as to what is going on in the author's mind.The love story between Howard Roark and Dominique Francon is unusual. These are two generally not likable people. Even the event that begins their relationship is what most would consider morally wrong. It doesn't seem to be personality that brings these two together. It's more about an attainment of an ideal.The Fountainhead is a classic read that also serves as a philosophical and political commentary. Those who have read, Atlas Shrugged, will find similarities in this book.  While it takes a while to feel engaged in the story, once the pieces begin to fall together, it becomes interesting. Recommended for those who enjoy novels with a political/philosophical slant.

summary:
When The Fountainhead was first published, Ayn Rand's daringly original literary vision and her groundbreaking philosophy, Objectivism, won immediate worldwide interest and acclaim. 

This instant classic is the story of an intransigent young architect, his violent battle against conventional standards, and his explosive love affair with a beautiful woman who struggles to defeat him. 

This edition contains a special afterword by Rand’s literary executor, Leonard Peikoff, which includes excerpts from Ayn Rand’s own notes on the making of The Fountainhead. As fresh today as it was then, here is a novel about a hero—and about those who try to destroy him.
